title: 104_hr2414
content: The "Youth Smoking Prevention Act of 1995" prohibits the Secretary of Health and Human Services from regulating tobacco and nicotine products under certain acts. Federal authority is established for regulating these products as a condition for states to receive the Federal block grant. The "Youth Smoking Prevention Act of 1995" prohibits the Secretary of Health and Human Services from regulating tobacco and nicotine products. The Act requires states to have laws prohibiting the sale of tobacco and nicotine products to individuals under 18 years old, with fines for violations similar to those for selling alcohol to minors. It is illegal for individuals under 18 to purchase tobacco products containing nicotine. First-time offenders may be fined up to $100, perform community service, or attend smoking hazard education. Repeat offenders face the same penalties plus mandatory education funded by fines. Additionally, presenting false identification for tobacco purchases is also prohibited. It is unlawful to sell individual cigarettes or packages with less than 20 cigarettes. Violators will be fined similar to selling alcohol to minors. Operating vending machines for cigarettes or smokeless tobacco products is also prohibited. It is prohibited to sell tobacco products through vending machines unless they are in a location under direct supervision, such as a private club, bar area, or workplace with minimal underage employees. It is unlawful to make tobacco products available to individuals under 18 in self-service displays without supervision. Distributing free samples of tobacco products to individuals under 18 is also prohibited. Violators will be fined according to state law. It is illegal to distribute tobacco and nicotine products through the mail to individuals under 18. Retail sales of these products must be supervised, with signs indicating the minimum purchase age. Violators will be fined as per state law. Each owner of a retail establishment selling tobacco products must inform employees about the prohibition of sales to individuals under 18. Employees must sign a form acknowledging this rule within 30 days of the enactment of this requirement. Employees must sign a form acknowledging prohibited acts related to the sale of cigarettes. Owners must retain these forms for inspections. Failure to comply may result in fines. Additionally, a license is required for retail sale of cigarettes, with penalties for sales without a license. The State is responsible for conducting annual random inspections of outlets selling tobacco products. The sale of tobacco and nicotine products must comply with regulations to prevent access by individuals under 18. Restrictions include no advertising on billboards near schools or playgrounds and no branding on items marketed to minors. Amendments are made to the Public Health Service Act regarding the sale of tobacco and nicotine products to minors, including changes in dates and noncompliance penalties. Enforcement measures are also updated to ensure compliance with regulations. Amendments to the Public Health Service Act allow states to use grant funds to enforce laws related to the sale of tobacco and nicotine products to minors. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must provide an annual report to Congress on states' compliance with enforcing laws related to tobacco and nicotine sales to minors.
